docs.lead_paragraph: One of every five Americans suffers from lower back pain, and the experience can be debilitating. Often, victims cannot drive long distances, hold their children or even walk. Now, researchers in Chicago report that a nontraditional therapy for back pain seems to work as well as more common treatments like analgesics and physical therapy, with fewer drugs.

headline.main: Osteopathy Proves Effective for Back Pain

docs.abstract: Researchers find that nontraditional therapy for lower back pain seems to work as well as more common treatments like analgesics and physical therapy, with fewer drugs; treatment is osteopathic manipulation, complex set of musculoskeletal techniques used by osteopathic physicians; report is in The New England Journal of Medicine (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a Darwinian law of nature that adults believe everything was better when they were young: music, books, movies, clothes, bagels and, of course, young people. But once in a while, adults are humbled. Something comes along that they look at wistfully, or maybe petulantly, and say: ''Hey! Where was that when I was a teenager?''

headline.main: A Sex Guide for Girls, Minus Homilies

docs.abstract: New wave of books and computer Web sites are aimed at adolescent girls, on ever-daunting topic of being a girl; these are sources where girls can learn about their bodies, minus medicalese and pious homilies; one book, Deal With It! A Whole New Approach to Your Body, Brain and Life as a Girl, offers adolescent girls brash, nonjudgmental picture of changes they are going through; photo (M)
docs.snippet: It is a Darwinian law of nature that adults believe everything was better when they were young: music, books, movies, clothes, bagels and, of course, young people.    But once in a while, adults are humbled. Something comes along that they look at...

docs.lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, pregnant women were almost universally warned to avoid strenuous activity. Running, cycling, skiing, horseback riding, singles tennis -- all were off limits. Only walking had widespread approval, and even that was to be limited to about a mile a day, preferably broken up into several short sessions. But faced with women's growing interest in exercise and sports and their desire to stay in shape while a new life takes shape within them, doctors gave exercise during pregnancy a second look. And to the surprise of many, medical research has shown that most women can safely continue to exercise throughout pregnancy, as long as they make some sensible adjustments to their routines. And for those women who were relatively inactive before conceiving and now wish to get in better shape before baby comes, it is even safe to begin exercise programs during pregnancy.

headline.main: Simple Adjustments for a Fit Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Second of two Personal Health columns on what is safe during pregnancy focuses on types of exercise and strenuous activities that are advisable, and types that are not; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Not so long ago, pregnant women were almost universally warned to avoid strenuous activity. Running, cycling, skiing, horseback riding, singles tennis -- all were off limits. Only walking had widespread approval, and even that was to be limited to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Subhash Mandal used to finish up his daily five-mile run feeling either exhausted or as if he had barely broken a sweat. ''I could never get a sense of how hard to push myself,'' said Mr. Mandal, 29, an actor who lives in Queens. Then, a personal trainer recommended that he try running with a heart-rate monitor strapped to his chest. Mr. Mandal says his runs are now more effective because he has an easy and accurate way to gauge his workout intensity. To help exercisers avoid either overdoing or underdoing it, experts advise establishing a target training zone: 50 to 90 percent of maximum heart rate, the fastest your heart is capable of beating. (A quick way to estimate maximum heart rate is to subtract your age from 220; thus, if you are 40, your maximum rate is about 180 and your target training zone is 90 to 162 beats a minute. To find out for certain, consult a doctor.)

headline.main: An Eye on the Heart for a Better Workout

docs.abstract: Fitness specialists are recommending that exercisers wear heart-rate monitor to help determine exercise efficiency; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There may be little common ground in the long-running debate over sex education, but people on all sides agree on this much: Until quite recently, teenage girls had little access to information about their bodies and their sexuality. In 1912, Margaret H. Sanger wrote a series of articles called What Every Girl Should Know for a radical newspaper, The Call. The articles later became a short book, dedicated to working girls of the world which described sexual anatomy, conception and birth, and even masturbation. But, said Judith E. Steinhart, the senior educator at Columbia University's health education program, few working girls ever got a chance to read it: postal officials confiscated it on grounds of obscenity.
docs.abstract: Brief excerpts from sex education books dating from early 1900's to 1971, offering advice on sex outside marriage; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When I headed into the waiting room at 2:19 the other afternoon, my 2:20 patient had disappeared. I knew he would be back in a minute or two, windblown and smelling of cigarette smoke, sheepishly tossing a crumpled pack into the trash. Our visits follow a depressing pattern. The only thing ever bothering him is a cough. He has asthma and recurrent bronchitis, admits to a pack a day, probably smokes more, and is frank about his current plans to quit: he has none. He is too stressed to try any more. As for cutting down: ditto.

headline.main: Smoke Two After Dinner and Call Me in the Morning

docs.abstract: Essay by Dr Abigail Zuger describes medications she prescribes for smoking-related conditions of her patient, a confirmed smoker; notes Supreme Court will consider question of whether Food and Drug Administration has authority to regulate tobacco same way it does other drugs; says even if FDA does regulate tobacco, effort would be aimed at children and teenagers because agency long ago acknowledged its limits in steering adults away; drawing (M)
